author: winkerpack
body:
So this can be seen. Here is a response I made directed to a mod and the mod team about them and the new rules/way the sub will be run in the time being. 

>Yall arent being too harsh, the issue is yall are being completely inconsistent. Heres some examples. 

>Pin a comment saying low quality content etc will result in a ban. Same day a mod pins a comment of a balloon boner?

>Rule was already no penny stocks, then a mod approves the 🌲🔨thread and makes a comment saying they're approving it. Even though they know the reason penny stocks are banned 

>Pin new comments saying influx of users will require cracking down. But mod a twitch thot 

>Bans being handed out to users who have been here 6+ months for personal grudges or dislike, not for breaking any sub rules. 

>I can keep going if you'd like. 

I get the cracking down. 100% understand it and agree something needed to be done. But to add to this comment. Posts should have been blocked from reaching all the minute wsbgod went viral and for a week straight the sub had the highest growth for all of reddit (but this was also around the same time the book was released. Funny how that works) . 

Theres no consistency in the bans

The rules still apple to the weekend thread? Basically every other major sub has a free talk thread where anything goes. 

I would suggest maybe making a free talk thread non market related where people can shitpost and meme and have a serious more market related thread. I really do think that would work. Enforce the new penny stock/pump and dump etc rules on the serious thread. Allow a thread for people just wanting to chat after hours without fear of getting banned. 

I think everyone can agree the handling of the sub and the last couple of weeks have been an absolute train wreck. I still beleive things can be fixed and this sub become enjoyable again, but the mods have really got to be consistent for this to happen, or the sub will turn into stocktwits for high schoolers asking if options trade on weekends. 

--winkerpack

author: skyliner12345
body:
Everyone knows it's impossible to time the market. We're all aware that this insane bull run isn't going to last forever, but nobody wants to be the idiot bear that blows their entire portfolio on QQQ puts, trying to do what Harvard educated hedge fund managers have been trying to do since the invention of the derivative. We've watched this thing go up and up and up, and anything less than a 1% week on week DOW increase feels like a pullback. Nothing can rock this market, not assassinations, not pandemics, not earnings misses, not a full scale nuclear attack. Stocks are trading at record high P/E's, with popular tickers like AAPL, MSFT, TSLA, AMD, and GOOG going fucking parabolic. In this market, anyone who's not an idiot is making money, but the question on every non-idiots's mind is:

How long will this last?

Some people will try to sway you with charts and graphs, talking about market indicators, yield curve inversion, put/call ratios, and other bullshit that's hasn't predicted the past, and will continue to not predict the future. What I do know is that the stock market is a hot topic right now. Friends that haven't said a word about stocks before seem to be opening Robinhood accounts with the hopes of getting rich. If you look at google trends, you'll see that terms like "options", "robinhood", and even "wallstreetbets" are exploding in popularity. Everyone wants in on the action right now, and when everyone is getting in, it's time for non-idiots to get out.

author: IceShaver
body:
I’d argue, that amongst the 1.4t in market cap of msft. XBOX’s value is a rounding error. Low margin business in a flat/declining environment. I’d be surprised if Xbox is worth more than 10-20b of Microsoft’s market cap, and that’s being generous.

MSFT’s entire growth in market cap in the last few years is almost entirely dependent on cloud growth. Computers and hardware business is low margin, and they’re not Apple. Office suits will outpace gdp growth yes as they have a monopoly. But the real reason of the growth ignoring the market multiple expansion factor is because of cloud.

author: FrothySeepageCurdles
body:
Okay I'm going to be really, really gay here and real talk.

I work for GM. I'm a software engineer. I've worked in the battery labs there. They have some of the world's most technologically advanced battery labs in the world.

The difference to the average person with all the extra tech and bells and whistles Tesla puts in is going to be very minute and insignificant once everyone catches up to where Tesla is. 

This whole Tesla thing is like being an apple or Android snob convinced their side is going to take over and be the sole dominant force. But in the end, the consumer doesn't care. The difference between your top Android phones and an iPhone is not actually that significant to the average person. They all do their calls, Facebook's, reddits, whatever all the same. Apple has lightning port, Android has type c. Tesla has their charging port, the rest of the world has the circle three pin one. Ok??? People in the long run aren't going to change their habits. 

The difference between Android and apple was much more significant in the early days. That's where we are right now with autonomous and EVs. In 5-10 years, they won't actually be all that different. They will have similar peripherals, cameras, sensors etc. 

Thesis: even if Tesla has a serious advantage in tech for a bit, it's not going to be that difficult for big players to copy and catch up. They won't be able to maintain a serious margin edge over the competition for a long time. The auto industry is oversaturated. 


Ok thanks for coming to my Ted talk. I don't advise buying anything mentioned. I'm all in MSFT calls.

body:
GM sells more cars in China than in the US. Hollywood sells more movie tickets in China than the US. Coca-Cola sells more drinks in Mexico + Brazil than it does in the US. Those are just a few quick examples that come to mind. For most American multinationals companies, the US today represents just a fraction of their total revenue and a fraction of their total operations.       
Plus for every Microsoft or Apple out there, there is a GE or a Unisys or a Kodak in terms of declining revenue.

author: LogicUpgrade
body:
Disney might modestly go up next week. If the pandemic situation gets serious though, we'll have lows before we have highs. But yeah if I were you and in the red with DIS, I'd also just wait. It's not a penny stock, or a meme or fad stock, it's a solid company.

>What am I missing that you guys all seem to know?

Eh I've made some of the same mistakes you've made, so I dunno what I know, but my working thesis is that:

1. First time when I heard "buy on weakness and sell on strength" it really didn't get through my thick skull. You gotta buy when there's a panic selloff, and sell when everyone is patting each other on the backs that stonks only go up.
2. Patience. When there's a sharp move up or down in the stock, it's always an overreaction first. If the movement is down, it'll recover (unless something fundamentally horrible happened, like accounting fraud and their entire ER is bullshit), if it's up, it'll fall a little (like after positive ER). Trade accordingly. Don't panic sell on a drop. WAIT. And sell when it recovers. Of course for this to work you need to know the dip is not fundamental and long-term.

I buy companies on a long-term uptrend, when they have a short term dip. Then wait for recovery.

Or if you invest long-term, pick companies not bothered by mostly anything, like Microsoft. Virus? China? Fuck if they care. Microsoft is on a roll. Steady subscription revenue, cloud services.

I'm not saying invest in Microsoft, but basically play it safe. One YouTuber likes to say "trade like a spoiled brat. Don't just buy anything, be extremely picky and very spoiled, buy only the best stocks on the safest entry points". And I mean, he's right.

What level you bought Disney at? I mean it's not like they're going bankrupt. The company is doing great. But it's seeing a bit of uncertainty right now around their parks business due to the virus, and Disney+ is a lot of air right now due to trial and short-term subscribers (although I think it'll do well by end of year).

Apple might drop on next ER (logistics, company is fine) so after ER might be a good entry point, that's another solid company, but I'd be a bit cautious next 2-3 months.

Anyway I've started just naming random stocks. I don't know shit. But h**ave patience and prefer repeated small wins, over risky big wins**. Small repeated wins get to the finish line.

Case in point, buying before ER and selling after is risky. But you know what's safe? Buying DIS few weeks before ER, selling 1-2 days BEFORE ER, when it peaks. This way it doesn't matter that the ER is. You trade expectations, not results.

author: BearSef
body:
My answer isn’t the one you’re looking for but here’s what I did.

I kept BTFDing thinking “Oooook, this has GOT to be the bottom.” It wasn’t. After seeing north of $75k wiped out in weeks (about 65% of my net value st the time) I finally just said “Uncle”, went all cash and waited....

I watched the market recover and decided to jump back in around March 2019. I missed out on a pretty stellar run the first 2 months of ‘19. Hindsight being 20/20, I could have done well getting in sooner but I have no regrets just waiting for the dust to settle.

One other piece of advice I can give from a diehard bull, DON’T FIGHT TRENDS. This is not a dip buying opportunity yet. No one knows when it’s truly going to be over until after. Bear it up in small doses now until it’s obvious the bleeding has stopped. There’s money to be made here but you aren’t going to will the market in any direction.

I’ve made nice money selling bull put spreads for the last 6 months. I finally threw in the towel and started selling bear call spreads. Opened a few on Tuesday with Apple. (I’m typing this from my iPhone...) I’ll go with the trends until the market shows me otherwise.

Live to fight another day.

author: techguru830
body:
Juniper is a terrible alternative for just about anything.  Fortinet and Palo Alto Networks are the best competitors when asking about Cisco competition in the network/ Security space (look at their stock performance as well).

I think Arista has some very good use cases where it makes the most sense, but I'm not sure if there are enough of those use cases to drive up a stock price.

body:
Juniper is a terrible alternative for just about anything.  Fortinet and Palo Alto Networks are the best competitors when asking about Cisco competition in the network/ Security space (look at their stock performance as well).

I think Arista has some very good use cases where it makes the most sense, but I'm not sure if there are enough of those use cases to drive up a stock price.

author: MaxAds1
body: Definitely sustainable. I’ve been trading for awhile now but just recently started options. You just have to be very proactive in buying offsetting positions when a trade isn’t going your way. Don’t buy too close to the money and make sure you have a decent amount of capital. As I commented above, if something isn’t going your way either sell immediately or if you feel it’s too late buy a longer dated offsetting position to mitigate losses. It’s actually insanely easy to turn a quick profit. Be cognizant of what’s going on in the news and if you’re selling spreads on ETFs just know what they’re made of. I’ll be posting weekly updates on what I’m doing starting tomorrow. I’m also doing some Yolos but making sure they’re at least 2 weeks out and selling quick once I make 750-1500.

author: michael_mullet
body:
As a counter point, the downside risk is much greater with OTM leaps. They can lose value if volatility slows, even if price doesn't drop.

I have to be cognizant of that, especially today.

author: dcbrah
body:
Familys been in it for 40+ years. When you first start out you are going to literally bust your ass until you hit the point you can hire a driver to deal with the work.

Lets say you have a machine that takes 20 cases of soda to fill and you have 20 machines around. Your talking about 400 cases at 20 pounds a case. 8000 pounds.

Your moving 8000 pounds at the store to your cart, from your cart to the truck, from the truck to the hand truck, from the handtruck into the machine. Can your back handle 32000 pounds and bending up and down each time you refill? Obviously rough math, but you get the idea.

Do you have a vehicle that can handle this?

Repair is dirty cheap if you have good machines and a good mechanic. Very easy to swap boards, validators, etc.

Stay away from snack and food machines if you are just starting out. Hassle to be cognizant of perishables and dates, etc. Need to consider how well candy holds as well - are you in Florida and have candy/chocolate machines?

You can absolutely crush it in the right location - but keep in mind its not get rich quick. It's get rich slow and by making sure your machines are all in a relatively close proximity (at least to start).

When we do the rough math it usually comes out that 50% of sales price is profit. So for $1 can of soda, $.50 goes towards gas, products cost, commission, operational expense etc.

How do you plan on moving the machines? Each time you move its $150-$200. Where do you store them when not using?

Just food for thought :)
